title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Aim

Introduce features of a Quarto presentation and demonstrate ways you can adapt this template for a presentation or any talk that relies on R for output.


Adding a right pointing arrow allows you to indent text



If you want to start a new line of text add a backward slash at the end of a line



You can make text bold by adding two asterisks on either end of a phrase


Add Hyperlink Text

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Making your Analysis Reproducible

Anything you wrap inside these back ticks will appear like so normally you can do this for technical parts


You can input highlighted text in line for example Ctrl+R.

title: Your Presentation Title Here
section: Code Chunk Explained a Bit More
text:
Code Chunk Explained a Bit More
The code chunks will include all your code, you can click Insert a new code chunk to your top right. Each chunk should have its own name. You can add a name after the first reserved word which refers to the language your code is in, this will be lowercase r for any R code. Follow the chunk name by a comma, for names try avoiding dashes, if there is an error with your code the error message will let you know which chunk has an issue. To evaluate, run the code, you will need to type eval = TRUE, if you do not want to run this code when you render the document change to FALSE. If you want to print your code in the slides add echo = TRUE.

library(network)

title: Your Presentation Title Here
section: Quarto allows you to have different tabs
text:
Quarto allows you to have different tabs

(a) Low(b) Moderate(c) High



low_prevalence <- rbinom(n = 100, size = 10, prob = 0.1)    # provide your own parameters
length(low_prevalence) 

[1] 100

head(low_prevalence)

[1] 0 1 0 1 2 0





moderate_prevalence <- rbinom(n = 100, size = 10, prob = 0.4)    # provide your own parameters
length(moderate_prevalence) 

[1] 100

head(moderate_prevalence)

[1] 4 5 5 5 6 5





high_prevalence <- rbinom(n = 100, size = 10, prob = 0.6)     # provide your own parameters
length(high_prevalence) 

[1] 100

head(high_prevalence)

[1] 6 8 8 3 4 4

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Summary for Results

library(psych)
library(knitr)

summary_samples <- rbind(low_smoking = describe(low_prevalence,quant=c(.25,.75) ), 
                         moderate_smoking = describe(moderate_prevalence,quant=c(.25,.75) ), 
                         high_smoking = describe(high_prevalence,quant=c(.25,.75)) )

summary_samples <- summary_samples[,c("mean","se", "sd", "min", "Q0.25", "median", "Q0.75", "max")]

kable(summary_samples)

Or the value of the median to describe your data 1

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Code Animations

Over 20 syntax highlighting themes available
Default theme optimized for accessibility

# Define a server for the Shiny app
function(input, output) {
  
  # Fill in the spot we created for a plot
  output$phonePlot <- renderPlot({
    # Render a barplot
    barplot(WorldPhones[,input$region]*1000, 
            main=input$region,
            ylab="Number of Telephones",
            xlab="Year")
  })
}

Learn more: Code Animations

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Line Highlighting

Highlight specific lines for emphasis
Incrementally highlight additional lines

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(subplot_kw={'projection': 'polar'})
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()

Learn more: Line Highlighting

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Easy Navigation
Quickly jump to other parts of your presentation
Toggle the slide menu with the menu button (bottom left of slide) to go to other slides and access presentation tools.
You can also press m to toggle the menu open and closed.

Learn more: Navigation

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Chalkboard
Free form drawing and slide annotations
Use the chalkboard button at the bottom left of the slide to toggle the chalkboard.
Use the notes canvas button at the bottom left of the slide to toggle drawing on top of the current slide.
You can also press b to toggle the chalkboard or c to toggle the notes canvas.

Learn more: Chalkboard
